content_preview.title: Kubernetes Ingress NGINX Reaches End of Life in March, Leaving Half of Cloud Native Environments Facing Urgent Migration
content_preview.summary: The community-maintained Ingress NGINX controller goes read-only in March 2026. With no future security patches and four new CVEs disclosed in February, organizations running roughly half of all Kubernetes ingress traffic must now choose between Gateway API and alternative controllers.
content_preview.body_excerpt:
## Overview

The Kubernetes project is days away from one of the most consequential infrastructure retirements in its history. In March 2026, the community-maintained Ingress NGINX controller will be officially retired, ending all releases, bug fixes, and security patches for software that currently powers roughly half of all cloud native environments, according to [Kubernetes Steering Committee](https://kubernetes.io/blog/2026/01/29/ingress-nginx-statement/). editor_notes.source_verification: All 5 sources verified as reputable and correctly cited. Primary sources include two official Kubernetes blog posts (retirement announcement Nov 2025, steering committee statement Jan 2026) and InfoQ. editor_notes.factual_accuracy: All major factual claims verified against primary sources: (1) 'only one or two people doing development work, on their own time, after work hours and on weekends' — verbatim from kubernetes.io/blog/2025/11/11; (2) 'about 50% of cloud native environments' — confirmed in kubernetes.io/blog/2026/01/29; (3) CVE-2025-1974 (IngressNightmare) CVSS 9.8 enabling RCE — confirmed by Datadog Security Labs; (4) four additional HIGH-severity CVEs in February 2026 (CVE-2026-1580, CVE-2026-24512, CVE-2026-24513, CVE-2026-24514) — confirmed by Datadog Security Labs; (5) exact quote 'To be abundantly clear: choosing to remain with Ingress NGINX after its retirement leaves you and your users vulnerable to attack' — verbatim from kubernetes.io/blog/2026/01/29; (6) Gateway API described as 'Ingress 2.0' — verbatim from opensource.googleblog.com/2026/02; (7) InGate being retired alongside Ingress NGINX — confirmed in kubernetes.io/blog/2025/11/11. No factual errors detected.
